bboxes.raw_text:
"The greatest attraction that
Arizona possesses continues to
be "Climate," concluded Valley
National Bank researchers in
discussing the states mild, dry
climate and its role in attract
ing both visitors and permanent
residents.


The report Is contained in the
current "Arizona Progress"
VNB's monthly business review.
Distributed to more than rs 900
business, professional and indus
trial leaders throughout the ma
ton and more than a dozen for
eign countries, the publication
makes a strong case for Ari-
zona's "near perfect weather."


Another portion of the current
issue is devoted to a special re-
view of Apache County and its

CLIMATE Is GREAT
SAYS VNB REVIEW

A second postponement on the
Salt River Project canal dry
up period due to cold weather
was announced. The project IL
currently releasing over 500 mil
lion gallons Of water a day for
frost orders to citrus growers
In order to help save the S.
million citrus crop in the VAL
ley.


Citrus growers have just
weathered one Of the severest
and most prolonged sieges Of
frigid air in Valley history. Paul
C. Kangieser, state climatolo-
gist, reported that the temper
atures of Is degrees and lower
recorded this past week by the
Weather Bureau in Phoenix rep
resent the longest period Of cold
weather below rs degrees since
the bureau began keeping records
here in 1895.


The new schedule calls for all
canals south of the Salt River
to be dry from midnight jan
uary 26 to midnight February 10,
weather permitting. During the
dry-up the perfect will replace
gate structures and line several
canals.

SRP CANAL DRY UP


RESCHEDULED HERE

The most recent sampling of
the labor ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
unemployment--by the Labor De-
partment' Bureau of Labor Sta
tistics, shows that unemployment
among nonwhite workers In
creased slightly from November
1862 to November 1868.


Nonwhite workers we're 22.5
percent Of the total unemployed
in November Of 1868, 2l.o per-
cent in November 1862. Of this
22.5 percent. ll.e we're male,
1915 female. Comparable figures
for November 1862 we're ll.2
percent ard o.8 percent.


For the long term unemploy-
ed--unemployed d weeks and
over--nonwhite workers we're
3l.6 in November 1868, 31.5 in
November 1862. Nonwhite males
we're us percent in 1868, 1914
in 1862. Females we're AL per-
cent in 1868. l2.1 in 1862.

advantages.


RELOCATING to the back pages
the usual statistics on Arizona
rising sales, income, nanufac-
turing and population. "Arizona
Progress" delves deeply into the
climate attractions Of the south
ern half of the state, finding:


in the winter and spring
months in particular, the wealth
err Is near perfect.


Daytime hours are charac-
terized by sunny skies and mild
temperatures, and during the
nights the air Is crisp and clear...


Tucson. which Is quite typi-
cal Of most Of Southern Arizona,
averages S6% of the possible sun
shine. This greatly exceeds the
amount other parts of the nation
normally receives"

Phoenix area families are urged
to turn on porchlights between
s pm. and 9 pm. Tuesday.
January %. to welcome their
neighbors participating In the
1864 Mothers March for the
March of Dimes.


Marchers will wear an official
badge. Men and teenagers who
participate will wear signs an
nouncing Tonight | Am A
Mother"


In addition to requesting con-
tributions for the work of the
National Foundation in Its battle
to conquer birth defects and ar
thrills, the Marchers will also
distribute educational material
of benefit to expectant mothers
and arthritis sufferers.


Families in the city of Phoe-
nix who are not visited by a
Marcher but who wish to con-
tribute are urged to call the
March of Dimes office. 264-0588,
and volunteer will come i'm
mediately to their address. Those
living in surrounding con1munit-
les, If not contacted, may send
their contributions to the March
of Dimes office, 1908 E. Thomas
Road, and the postmark will
credit their community
campaign.


The Mothers March origina-
ted In Phoenix IA years ago, and
has since become a nationwide
tradition.

Visitors to Merida, in the
Yucatan peninsula Of Mexico, are
usually fascinated by the color
fully painted, oblong wood tubs
sold in the market places. Because
of their junior dimensions, shall
low depressions, and wide counters
at either end, these are often mis-
taken for children's bathtubs.


However, they are actually
laundry tubs called "bateas" -
used chiefly by Magyar Indians.
The Mayas, who are noted for
their cleanliness, set these bateas
at a convenient height on wooden
horses, fill them with we'll water
- and suds their laundry almost
every day.

ATLANTA, Ca. = Gov. Carl
Sanders was asked by the local
branch Of the NAACP to issue
Immediately an executive order
banning discrimination in public
places.


Leon Cox, NAACP field sec
rotary for Georgia, and DR.. c.
Miles Smith, Atlanta branch
president, asked the Governor to
issue the order in a letter on
Jan. Is following a sit-in dem
onstration at a city motel that
resulted in the arrest Of Is
persons.


Besides Mr.. Cox, Atlanta
NAACP officials jailed in the at
tempt to desegregate the Heart
of-Atlanta Motel. Saturday night,
Jan. IL, included DR.. Clinton
Warner, branch vice-president;
Mrs. Eunice Cooper, branch sec
rotary: and the Rev. Joseph Boone
branch church committee chair
man.


Arrested also we're the Rev.
Wyatt Tee Walker and Harry H.
Boyle, officials of the Southern
Christian Leadership c conference
and John Lewis, chairman of the
Student Nonviolent Coordinating
Committee.


Three co-eds among those
Jailed we're Joyce Barrett and
Prathia Hall Of Philadelphia; and
Judy Richardson of Tarrytown,
MY.

GEORGIA GOVERNOR ASKED


IN HOTEL IMMIGRATION TRY

Miss Richardson, a student
at Swarthmore College, fell to
the pavement during a scuffle
with a motel employee outside
the establishment.


Police rushed Miss Richard
son to the all-white Georgia Bap-
fist Hospital. DR.. c. Miles Smith,
branch president. went along.
Hospital attendants refused to ex-
anime the coed. at first. How
ever. upon DR.. Smiths demand,
they did and found her uninjured.


While at the hospital. DR.. Smith
and Miss Richardson decided to
integrate the coffee shop. The
management baked at serving
them. but relented. upon DR..
Smith s insistence.


The demonstrators sat In the
motel nearly three hours before
they we're jailed. Police had re-
fused to arrest them until war
rants we're issued.


In the past when police have
arrested demonstrators on their
own for trespassing, proprietors
have often declined to prosecute
the cases in court.


Heart-of-Atlanta Motel re-
portedly refused to join IA other
motels and hotels that earlier
had agreed to accept Negroes.
